title: \(\mathrm{SU(N)}\) lattice gauge theories with Physics-Informed Neural Networks
text:
Preamble
In Quantum Mechanics the fundamental equations are the Schrödinger equations. One depends on time, determining the evolution of a physical state: \[i \partial_t \ket{\psi} = H \ket{\psi}\]
The other is the eigenvalue equation for the \(n\)-th eigenstate \(\psi_n\): \[H \ket{\psi}_n = E \ket{\psi}_n\]
If the are able to solve the latter, the time evolution reads: \[
\ket{\psi(0)} = \sum_n c_n \ket{\psi}_n
\, \to \,
\ket{\psi(t)} = \sum_n c_n e^{-i E_n t} \ket{\psi}_n
\]
Note: Solving the Schrödinger equations can be simpler for some values of the parameters in the Hamiltonian (e.g. eq can use perturbation theory). For others, we have to resort to numerical methods.


Summary of the paper
In this paper I proposed an algorithm to solve the eigenvalue equation with a neural network. The usefulness is the ability to solve the eigenvalue equation with a form of unsupervised learning, for values the coupling where the analytic solution is not known.
The key elements of originality are:

This has never been done for lattice gauge theories, and has the potential of overcoming the exponential curse of the Hilbert space size scaling.
I define and successfully test a procedure to compute the coupling dependence of the solution (i.e. the renormalization flow of the eigenfunctions and energies)
The method is general and can be applied also to learn the dependence on other parameters of the Hamiltonian
This is an Hamiltonian method. As such, it does not suffer from the typical Monte Carlo hindrances: critical slowing down, topological freezing, sign problem, etc.

I am a theoretical computational physicist in the field of High Energy Physics. In my work I use computers to provide high-precision quantitative predictions of physical quantities, in those regimes where analytic solutions are out of reach.

Current employer: University of Bern
Job title: Postdoctoral Researcher
Education: PhD in Theoretical Physics

My main areas of interest are:

Quantum Field Theories on the lattice, QCD phenomenology
Machine Learning for scientific applications, Physics-Informed Neural Networks
Markov chain Monte Carlo, Bayesian algorithms

title: A summary of my personal interests and work mindset
text:
I believe that meaningful work comes from genuine interest, commitment, and a positive attitude. I strive to approach each day with enthusiasm and a strong sense of responsibility, motivated not only by outcomes but by the process of learning, improving, and contributing along the way.
I value environments where people care about what they do and where collaboration, respect, and growth are encouraged. When I feel aligned with the mission and culture of a workplace, I naturally invest my energy and effort to help it succeed. I take pride in being reliable, consistent, and proactive, and I am always willing to step up when something needs to be done.
I am a hard worker by nature, but also a curious one. I enjoy learning new skills, adapting to new challenges, and expanding my perspective. Feedback is something I welcome, as I see it as an opportunity to grow and refine my approach. Over time, my goal is to continuously add more value to the environment I am part of and to grow alongside it.
For me, work is at its best when passion, purpose, and progress come together—creating a space where both the individual and the organization can thrive.
